title: Tiwai Point smelter decision delayed
text:
Wednesday 1 Jul 2015 9:08 a.m. 
The smelter contributes around $525 million to the Southland community (file) 
Energy bosses have given Tiwai Point aluminium smelter a last-minute extension to decide whether to terminate their massive electricity contract. 
New Zealand Aluminium Smelters Ltd (NZAS) was supposed to give Meridian Energy notice on whether they would continue purchasing power today, but that has been pushed out to August 3 with all terms unchanged. 
It's a massive contract for the power company, with Tiwai consuming around a seventh of the country's electricity production. 
Meridian chief Executive Mark Binns says the extension was agreed on last night. 
"NZAS has been in discussions with a number of parties, including Meridian, with respect to its electricity requirements at its Tiwai Point smelter. NZAS requires more time to fully analyse its options before making a decision," he said in a statement. 
"We think it is in all parties' interests to ensure that a decision is based on the most complete information." 
The smelter contributes around $525 million to the Southland community and employs hundreds of people.
